notesStmt.note: De Ricci, Seymour, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2041, no. 97.

Free Library of Philadelphia, A Descriptive Catalogue of the John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts in the Free Library of Philadelphia, compiled by Edwin Wolf, 2nd, with an introduction by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach (Philadelphia: The Free Library, 1937), p. 135, no. 121.

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript contains a Book of Hours, Use of Rome.

msItem.title: Book of Hours, Use of Rome
Office of the Virgin, Use of Rome
Office of the Dead, Rome use
Variation of the prayer to the Virgin, "Sancta Maria succurre miseris" (added by contemporary hand)

supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper corner recto

p.catchwords: Vertical near the gutter verso; fols. 22v, 32v, 42v, 52v, 62v, 72v, 82v, 92v, 102v, 112v, 122v, 142v, 152v, 160v, 170v, 180v, 190v

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled in ink; one column of thirteen lines (calendar, fols. 1-12, frame-ruled in one column of seventeen lines); written area: 68x50 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Two historiated initials, three decorated initials, five foliate borders; one- and two-line initials in red and blue throughout; rubrication throughout
13rFour line historiated initial D, Virgin and Child
85rHistoriated partial foliate border, saint and a crane
133rDecorated initial D, penitent King David in lower margin
158rHistoriated partial foliate border, kings and birds
158rDecorated initial D, King David in lower margin

binding.p: Nineteenth-century, red morocco, gilt inner edges with clasp, LIBER PRECIS stamped in gold on spine; in red case with morocco-backed spine, gold-stamped HORAE B. M. VIRGINIS M.S. XV. SAEC.

history.provenance: Abbey of Passignano, Italy (late fifteenth century); bookplate of John Morgan, Rubislaw House, Aberdeen; sold London, Sotheby's (26 February 1900) to Tregaskis (cat. 463, 2 Apr. 1900, n. 388; cat. 468, 9 July 1900, n. 500); Maggs (after 1900); bookplate of John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936

keywords.term: Illumination of books and manuscripts, Gothic
